subject: Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: ... For one thing, it s not my approach .  It s the way JUnit is designed to be used.  I ve seen Kent make the same point. ... Wondering is good.  Research
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@d...> wrote:
> So said Mike Colbert <mbcolbert@y...> on 12/14/2002

> >> >just exactly
> >> >what is it that makes your approach so superior that you will
> >> >immediately discount all others as inadequate?

For one thing, it's not "my approach". It's the way JUnit is designed
to be used. I've seen Kent make the same point.

> >Oh, but it's my approach that was attacked with a groundless claim.
> >Sorry for wondering why.

Wondering is good. Research with an open mind is better.

I try to make a habit of making bold, confrontational statements. It
challenges people (you obviously took it as a challenge), get's their
attentions, and stirs up discussion. These are all good things IMO.
My intention is not to attack, just to startle.

However, I do believe what I expounded is the best way to do it. The
*best* way, not the *only* way. In fact I don't always do it the way
I described, but I try to. Just like I strive to have only a single
assertion per test (sometimes to the extent of extracting a complex
test into a local assert method). Again, I didn't come up with these
ideas, I just see the truth & value in them.

> It may be that Dave was describing a general-purpose,
> one-size-fits-all approach that could be optimized in your specific
> case. If you ask him civilly, I'm sure he'll respond. If you feel he
> was being uncivil towards you, then be the bigger man and tell him
> so, civilly. I missed his part of the exchange, so I can't say.

I don't think I was being uncivil. Just putting forth what I think is
the *best* way to do it. The *best* isn't always doable... but like
the simplest thing, you should alwasy at least consider it.

> If you write code first, then "likely" add tests, why is that TDD? I
> don't think it is.

No. To be doing TDD you don't write code without a failing test that
requires it in order to pass. THAT is TDD.

Kent's book does a fabulous job of showing you *What TDD is*.
Everyone should buy it & read it repeatedly until the binding falls apart.

*ahem* You should also buy my book when it comes out. It's goal is to
show you *how to do TDD in Java*. Hopefull it will have a lay-flat
binding so you can easily have it open next to your keyoard.

Dave
